topic.title: Removing a Ceph Monitor Node
topic.abstract: Steps for removing Ceph monitor nodes.The process to remove Ceph monitor nodes, depends on how they have been deployed - either on the controller node or on a separate/dedicated resource node.

section.title: Notes
section.p: It is recommended to maintain an odd number of Ceph monitors because the Paxos protocol is being used by Ceph monitors to form a consensus. Although clusters can be deployed with a single monitor, we strongly recommend to deploy three monitors on independent nodes for production usage to avoid a single point of failure of the monitor service.
For this reason, it is recommended to maintain at least three and an odd number of Ceph monitors.

section.title: To Remove Monitor Nodes from the Controller Node
section.p: Permanent removal of a monitor is not supported when the monitor service is installed on the controller node. However, to temporarily bring down the service on the controller node (for maintenance purposes), perform the following steps:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Stop the monitor service running on the specific host by running the following commands: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-stop.yml --limit <mon-node-to-remove>
The hostname of the node can be found in the list generated from the output of the following command: grep hostname ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml
Remove the monitor service from the cluster:ceph mon remove <ceph-mon-host> You can determine the value for <ceph-mon-host> by using the ceph -s command.

section.title: Remove Monitor Nodes from a Separate/Dedicated Node
section.p: Perform the following steps to remove a monitor node from a separate/dedicated node.

ol.li: Login to the monitor node to be removed.
Stop the monitor service running on the specific host by running the following commands :service ceph-mon@<ceph-mon-host> stop
Remove the monitor service:ceph mon remove <ceph-mon-host>
Edit the servers.yml file and remove the host section from the file.vim ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Remove the Monitor node from Cobbler:sudo cobbler system remove --name <node-name>
For example: If you want to remove the mon1 (monitor node), execute the following command:sudo cobbler system remove --name mon1

section.title: Removing the Node from Monitoring
section.p: Once you have removed the Ceph Monitor node, the alarms against them will trigger so there are additional steps to take to resolve this issue.

You will want to SSH to each of the Monasca API servers and edit the /etc/monasca/agent/conf.d/host_alive.yaml file to remove references to the Ceph Monitor node you removed. This will require sudo access.
